citation.article-title: Corynebacterium sputi sp. nov., isolated from the sputum of a patient with pneumonia.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Corynebacterium sputi sp. nov.
Corynebacterium sputi (spu′ti. L. gen. n. sputi of sputum).
Cells are Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, non-motile rods.
Colonies are cream–yellow, circular, convex, dry and approximately 0.2–2 mm in diameter on Columbia blood agar after 48 h incubation at 37 °C.
Tween 80 encourages growth of the organism.
Urea is hydrolysed, but aesculin, gelatin and hippurate are not hydrolysed.
Acid is produced from d-glucose, but not from l-arabinose, glycogen, inulin, d-lactose, maltose, d-mannitol, raffinose, d-ribose, d-sorbitol, starch, sucrose, trehalose, or d-xylose.
Activity is detected for α-glucosidase, lipase C8, lipase C14, leucine arylamidase, pyrazinamidase and naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase.

No activity is detected for acid and alkaline phosphatases, arginine dihydrolase, chymotrypsin, cysteine arylamidase, esterase C-4, α-fucosidase, α-galactosidase, β-galactosidase, β-glucuronidase, β-glucosidase, N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, α-mannosidase, pyrrolidonyl arylamidase, trypsin or valine arylamidase.
The long-chain cellular fatty acids are of the straight-chain saturated and monounsaturated types, with C16 : 0, C18 : 0 and C18 : 1ω9c predominating; tuberculostearic acid is present.
The type strain, IMMIB L-999T (=DSM 45148T=CCUG 55795T), was isolated from the sputum of a patient with pneumonia.
